citation.article-title: The taxonomic status of the fermentative halophilic anaerobic bacteria: description of Haloanaerobiales ord. nov., Halobacteroidaceae fam. nov., Orenia gen. nov. and further taxonomic rearrangements at the genus and species level.

p.s: Description of Haloanaerobiales ord. nov.
Haloanaerobiales (Ha. lo.an.ae.ro'.bi.รก.les. Haloanaerobiaceae type family of the order: -ales ending to denote an order: Haloanaerobiales the Haloanaerobiaceae order)
Gram-negative rods with Gram-negative cell wall type.
Halophilic.
Obligately anaerobic.
A member of the phylogenetically defined Clostridium/Bacillus subphylum of Gram-postive Bacteria.
The order can be differentiated from other major clusters of this subphylum by a set of 16s rDNA signature nucleotides.
G+C content of DNA ranges from 27-40 mol%.
The obvious bifurcation of the branching pattern of members of the order Haloanaerobiales, with two major clusters of similar phylogenetic depth, can be interpreted in two ways.
Firstly, if one maintains a single family, the two major clusters could be elevated to two families.

Based on the distinct differences in 16S rDNA percent similarity and the presence of a high number of signature nucleotides, we feel that the separation of the family into two families Haloanaerobiaceae and Halobacteroidaceae is justified.

Although we are aware of the lack of multiple phenotypic characters which would be helpful in supporting this conclusion, the lack of spore formation is observed in all members of Haloanaerobiaceae, while the majority of members of Halobacteroidaceae are spore formers (Table 1).
The present lack of comprehensive comparative studies of physiological and chemotaxonomic properties involving all species in parallel leaves an incomplete data set.
Considering the phylogenetic distinctness of these lineages one can expect greater phenotypic differences to exist.
The type family of the order is Haloanaerobiaceae.
The original description of this family, based on the analysis of two species of two genera, still holds except for an extension of the range of G+C content.
Gram-negative rods, non-motile or motile by means of peritrichous flagella, non spore-forming, chemoorganotrophs, obligate anaerobes, halophilic, growing optimally at NaCl concentrations of ~10-15%.
The G+C content of the DNA ranges from 27-40%.
Distinct genomic properties are present in the 16S rDNA primary and secondary structure, defined by a set of signature nucleotides.
The type genus of the family Haloanaerbium (Zeikus et al. [13]).
Additional genera are Halocella and Halothermothrix.
